update.description:
Hi There,

My apologies about the delay.  As discussed, I have developed an updated version of the pinger plugin based on the feedback I have received from Brian and Carlos.  Hopefully this will address the listed concerns.

Operation of the plugin can be demonstrated by executing the vmrc.launch file.  This version of the launch file has been modified to launch the sensor version of the WAM-V which now includes a pinger detector.  The initial position of the pinger will be set to the  default specified in the SDF file.  

A pair of nodes have also been included to set and visualise the position of the pinger and the resulting message.  Executing the pinger.launch file will initialise these nodes with the pinger positions specified in the pinger.yaml file in the robotx\_gazebo/config folder.  These positions have been chosen to lie on the pinger transit position of the default course.  Visualisation will appear on the topics /pinger/marker/signal and /pinger/marker/ground\_truth.  These can be visualised in RViz.   

As suggested by Carlos the pinger program is now part of the usv\_gazebo\_plugins package.  Noise generation is performed using the SDF noise model using code written by Brian. 

Note: I have used a set of example plugin files as the base of the plugin.  For this reason, the copyright date is quite old.  I am not sure of the process required to get this date updated.  

* Add usv\_msgs package. This includes a range bearing message used by the pinger plugin
* Add the pinger plugin to the wamv\_gazebo package. The wamv\_gazebo\_sensors.urdf file has been modified to add support for the pinger plugin.
* Add nodes to set the position of the simulated pinger, and visualise the resultant pinger message. pinger.yaml - set the possible positions of the pinger. pinger.launch - Launch the position and visualisation nodes.
* Decrease sensor noise to more clearly allow debugging of the simulation.
* Update variable names and comments to be compliant with the Gazebo style guide.
* _Set the sensor WAM-V as the default model_ Fix the doxygen generation
update.title: Acoustic pinger

content.raw:
Jonathan,

Thank you so much! It seems you’ve provided the whole tutorial. I will work on the writeup for our Wiki but in the meantime I think we should go forward with your merge.

Best,

Michael
content.html:
Jonathan,

Thank you so much! It seems you’ve provided the whole tutorial. I will work on the writeup for our Wiki but in the meantime I think we should go forward with your merge.

Best,

Michael

content.raw:
Sure, 

In this sub-branch, I have already added the pinger plugin to the sensor version of the ASV, which is also now the default.  As such, the minimal version of the instructions would be the following;

    roslaunch robotx_gazebo vmrc.launch
    roslaunch robotx_gazebo pinger.launch

Before the result can be visualised, a valid transformation between the world and the pose of the sensor will be required.  This can created by the user, or alternately the existing localisation example can be used;

```shell
roslaunch wamv_gazebo localization_example.launch
```

The output of the pinger can now be visualised using RViz on the topics;

    /pinger/marker/ground_truth
    /pinger/marker/signal

Note that the pinger launch file is not required for the operation of the pinger plugin itself.   It starts two nodes, `set_pinger_position.py` and `pinger_visualisation.py`.  These are not required for the operation of the pinger itself but provide the following;

* Setting the pinger position to a random place in the current VMRC courses entry/exit gates
* Generates a marker for RViz showing the ground truth position in the `map` frame
* Produce a marker for RViz showing the current range and bearing of the sensor return

Note:  this is configuration does not currently produce a transform between the `map` and `utm` frame generated by the localisation example.  Visualisation of the ground truth requires the map frame to be set manually.

The output of the pinger is a custom message of type `usv_msgs/RangeBearing` on the topic `/pinger/range_bearing`.  Each published message consists of a single sampled return that has been converted to a range and bearing in the frame of reference of the sensor.

If the user is creating a custom WAM-V configuration based on the existing .xacro files, simply adding;

    <xacro:wamv_pinger name="pinger_wamv" position="1.0 0 -1.0" />

Should be sufficient to add the pinger sensor to the vehicles model.  The position can be configured by simply changing the position offset in the tag.  More detailed changes, including changing the `frame_id` of the plugin, and the noise model can be performed by altering the `wamv_pinger.xacro` file.

Please let me know if you would like further information.

Regards,

Jonathan.

The output of the pinger can now be visualised using RViz on the topics;

/pinger/marker/signal

Note that the pinger launch file is not required for the operation of the pinger plugin itself. It starts two nodes, set_pinger_position.py and pinger_visualisation.py. These are not required for the operation of the pinger itself but provide the following;

Note: this is configuration does not currently produce a transform between the map and utm frame generated by the localisation example. Visualisation of the ground truth requires the map frame to be set manually.

The output of the pinger is a custom message of type usv_msgs/RangeBearing on the topic /pinger/range_bearing. Each published message consists of a single sampled return that has been converted to a range and bearing in the frame of reference of the sensor.

If the user is creating a custom WAM-V configuration based on the existing .xacro files, simply adding;

Jonathan.

content.raw:
Jonathan,

Thanks! Things seem to be working on my end. I’d like to put together a tutorial that explains how to get up and running with this plugin \(and also confirm that it’s working as expected\). I can put this together, but your input would be very helpful: what do you think would be the major steps that a new user would want to take to work with this plugin?

Many thanks,

Michael
content.html:
Jonathan,

Thanks! Things seem to be working on my end. I’d like to put together a tutorial that explains how to get up and running with this plugin (and also confirm that it’s working as expected). I can put this together, but your input would be very helpful: what do you think would be the major steps that a new user would want to take to work with this plugin?

Many thanks,

Hi There,

My apologies about the delay.  As discussed, I have developed an updated version of the pinger plugin based on the feedback I have received from Brian and Carlos.  Hopefully this will address the listed concerns.

Operation of the plugin can be demonstrated by executing the vmrc.launch file.  This version of the launch file has been modified to launch the sensor version of the WAM-V which now includes a pinger detector.  The initial position of the pinger will be set to the  default specified in the SDF file.

Executing the pinger.launch file will initialise these nodes with the pinger positions specified in the pinger.yaml file in the robotx\_gazebo/config folder. update.title: Acoustic pinger

content.raw:
Hi MIchael,

This error is caused by catkin attempting to compile the plugin in parallel with building the custom messages. Compiling with a single thread using the command `catkin_make -j1` will cause this to build successfully.

A dependency can be manually added by including the following line in the CMakeLists of the usv\_gazebo\_plugins package;

`add_dependencies(usv_gazebo_pinger_plugin usv_msgs_generate_messages_cpp)`

This will allow the package to be compiled in parallel.  I will update my repo with this code.

Regards,

Jonathan.
content.html:
Hi MIchael,

This error is caused by catkin attempting to compile the plugin in parallel with building the custom messages. Compiling with a single thread using the command catkin_make -j1 will cause this to build successfully.

A dependency can be manually added by including the following line in the CMakeLists of the usv_gazebo_plugins package;

add_dependencies(usv_gazebo_pinger_plugin usv_msgs_generate_messages_cpp)

This will allow the package to be compiled in parallel. I will update my repo with this code.

Regards,

Jonathan.

content.raw:
Hi Jonathan,

I’m testing this now. When I attempt to build, catkin\_make fails the first two times because it is missing usv\_msgs/RangeBearing.h. On the third time through it builds successfully. Do you see the same thing if you build from scratch?

Best,

Michael
content.html:
Hi Jonathan,

I’m testing this now. When I attempt to build, catkin_make fails the first two times because it is missing usv_msgs/RangeBearing.h. On the third time through it builds successfully. Do you see the same thing if you build from scratch?

Best,

Michael

Please let me know if you would like me to make any further alterations.

Regards,

Jonathan.

Thanks Brian,

Please let me know if you would like me to make any further alterations.

Regards,

Jonathan.

This is really great - thank you @JonathanWheare .

It will take me some time to get to this, but from your description it looks like a really nice contribution.
